data.title: The Seminar — Office Ladies
data.text:
TRANSCRIPT

Office Ladies | Episode 146 - The Seminar

Jenna [00:00:03] I'm Jenna Fischer.

Angela [00:00:04] And I'm Angela Kinsey.

Jenna [00:00:06] We were on The Office together.

Angela [00:00:07] And we're best friends.

Jenna [00:00:08] And now we're doing the ultimate Office rewatch podcast just for you.

Angela [00:00:12] Each week, we will break down an episode of The Office and give exclusive behind the scenes stories that only two people who were there can tell you.

Jenna [00:00:19] We're the Office Ladies. Hello!

Angela [00:00:23] Hi there.

Jenna [00:00:25] Angela, can I interest you in a seminar? It's a podcasting seminar.

Angela [00:00:31] Oh, are we going to a seminar?

Jenna [00:00:33] Yeah. What do you think? I put up some fliers.

Angela [00:00:36] Is it just going to be us and Sam and Cassi?

Jenna [00:00:39] Yes, at lunch, actually. But never mind.

Angela [00:00:42] There will be sandwiches. There will be sandwiches.

Jenna [00:00:43] There will. This is season seven, episode 14. It's called The Seminar. It was directed by B.J. Novak and written by Steve Healey. Steve Healey was a new writer for us in season seven. He had previously written for The Late Show with David Letterman and 30 Rock. He was a co-executive producer on Veep. I did a little diving on him, and I found out- was reminded actually that he wrote this book with Vali Chandrasekaran. Remember, he played Hot Doctor on Diwali?

Angela [00:01:13] Yes.

Jenna [00:01:14] They wrote a book together called The Ridiculous Race. I remembered this. They decided to race around the world.

Angela [00:01:22] The two of them?

Jenna [00:01:22] Just the two of them. They started in L.A. They each had to go in different directions. And there was one rule, which was that they couldn't use any planes. And they had to see who got back to L.A. first.

Angela [00:01:34] And they went around the world?

Jenna [00:01:35] Around the world. At one point, the way Steve got out of L.A. was that he arranged for himself to ride on a container ship from Long Beach to Shanghai.

Angela [00:01:46] What?!

Jenna [00:01:47] Yeah. They wrote all about it in their book.

Angela [00:01:51] I want to read this book.

Jenna [00:01:52] It's insane, right?

Angela [00:01:53] I mean, a container ship. Anything can happen out there.

Jenna [00:01:58] I know!

Angela [00:01:58] They're out in the wide open ocean.

Jenna [00:02:00] I mean, how do you do that? How do you convince someone to let you ride on a container ship?

Angela [00:02:07] I don't know. I guess I'll have to read the book.

Jenna [00:02:10] Steve also wrote a book called The Wonder Trail, where he traveled through Central and South America. And he also wrote a novel called How I Became a Famous Novelist, which won the 2010 Thurber Prize for American Humor.

Angela [00:02:24] That's so cool.

Jenna [00:02:25] Yeah. So he's been writing a lot of books since we saw him. But he also wrote this episode. Would you like a summary?

Angela [00:02:33] Yes.

Jenna [00:02:33] As a ploy to get new clients, Andy hosts a business seminar in the conference room and enlists the help of his fellow employees. Jim mysteriously skips out after recognizing one of the attendees. Michael and Holly start to reconnect by pretending to be a Greek couple. Oscar and Pam help Erin play Gabe in an online game of Scrabble.

Angela [00:02:56] Well, Jenna, fantastic summary. I know you have some hot fast facts for us. And after that, I have a little digital clutter.

Jenna [00:03:03] Well, buckle in, everyone. Let's get started. Fast fact number one: this episode aired on January 27th, 2011, and it won its timeslot for the night. Again.

Angela [00:03:16] Woo!

Jenna [00:03:16] Way to go, Office! Before this episode aired, they had just announced to the press that Will Ferrell would be joining us for a four episode arc at the end of this season. And there was a lot of buzz. Do you remember the buzz?

Angela [00:03:31] We were so excited.

Jenna [00:03:32] Oh, my gosh.

Angela [00:03:33] I mean, we were like sad/ excited. We were like, oh, no, Steve. Oh, Will Ferrell!

Jenna [00:03:37] Yeah. So they released this news on purpose. They wanted the buzz. It was a bit of a red herring.

Angela [00:03:45] Ooh, intrigue.

Jenna [00:03:47] They were trying to distract from something else.

Angela [00:03:50] And what was the other thing? I know you're going to tell us.

Jenna [00:03:53] They were trying to distract everyone from the big cameo guest star that kicks off this episode. Ricky Gervais is as David Brent has come to Scranton.

Angela [00:04:05] David Brent and Michael Scott meet. I mean, for any Office fan, this is a huge moment!

Jenna [00:04:12] Huge. And that is fast fact number two. We're going to break down this cold open and tell you all about Ricky coming to The Office.

Angela [00:04:20] Kick it off.

Jenna [00:04:21] Well, it all starts at some elevator bays.

Angela [00:04:24] Yeah. Michael runs into a very nice English fella who's getting off the elevator who says his name is David Brent. Michael immediately does a British accent. Or his attempt to. And then David Brent shares that he also does accents and characters.

Jenna [00:04:40] And then they go back and forth with their various characters that they do. They are delighting one another. Oh, my gosh.

Angela [00:04:47] Kindred spirits. David then says, Comedy is a place where the mind goes to tickle itself. That's what she said.

Jenna [00:04:55] Michael can't believe it.

Angela [00:04:56] This is his soul mate.

Jenna [00:04:58] Yes!

Angela [00:04:58] You thought Holly was his soul mate. Here it is.

Jenna [00:05:02] Yeah. Michael hugs him goodbye.

Angela [00:05:05] Yes. And then David says, Are you guys hiring? He said, No.

Jenna [00:05:09] Mm hmm.

Angela [00:05:10] And then he said, Well, think of me if something comes up. And he leaves, and Michael's like, What a nice guy.

Jenna [00:05:15] I'm sure you can imagine, we got a lot of mail about this.

Angela [00:05:17] Oh, yeah.

Jenna [00:05:18] I'll kick it off. First up is Karen C from Delaware, as well as many others, who would like to know, Where was the cold open supposed to be? Because it doesn't look like the industrial park where Dunder Mifflin is located.

Angela [00:05:31] Karen, I feel seen. I wrote in my notes, Where the heck is this elevator?

Jenna [00:05:36] Well, while we were shooting the episode The Sting, you remember that one where they meet Danny Cordray? Well, Ricky Gervais happened to be in town for, I don't know, a celebrity appearance or something, and he just volunteered to come in and do a scene for us. He said, I want to do a scene with Steve.

Angela [00:05:53] Awesome.

Jenna [00:05:53] Yeah. So they were like, Well, we're at this location. Why don't you come on down? So we shot it there at that same place, at that those same elevators, you know, the one where Michael wonders if the buttons even work.

Angela [00:06:05] Mm hmm.

Jenna [00:06:06] Randy said he had to create a stealth call sheet. He did not put Ricky's name down. They did not want this cameo to get out. They lied to NBC about it!

Angela [00:06:15] They have a habit of doing that.

Jenna [00:06:17] Yes, they didn't want any promos. That's why they did the whole Will Ferrell press release. All of it. But guess what?

Angela [00:06:24] What?

Jenna [00:06:25] The week before the episode aired, it got out. Hollywood Reporter ran a story that Ricky was going to be on. Paul Lieberstein was even quoted for the episode, but he was very careful. He wouldn't say how or why Ricky was going to be on the show. So it did leak a little bit. But we tried.

Angela [00:06:42] We tried not to leak.

Jenna [00:06:44] We made it all the way to the week before. Next up, we have a fan question from Amanda C in Indiana who says, I just have to know how much of the cold open was scripted. It almost seems like Ricky is genuinely breaking and reacting to Steve's version of Michael. His laugh just seems so genuine. I want to know everything about their interaction while filming. Well, Amanda, there was a script for this cold open between the two of them. Our writers got together and wrote 11 versions of this scene. In the scripted version, they were on the elevator together, like one of them would be on and the other would enter and this would start the conversation. But when they got there on the day, they kind of realized, you know what, these two guys are really funny. We're just going to let them talk outside this elevator bay. And that's what they did.

Angela [00:07:34] I reached out to our editor, Dave Rogers, and I was like, Dave, were there any alts for the scene? I mean, come on. And he said, you know, Ange, we put the best stuff in the bloopers. It was mostly Steve cracking Ricky up that day.

Jenna [00:07:48] That's what I remember hearing.

Angela [00:07:50] Dave went on to say that he wasn't there the day they filmed this, but he really remembers editing the bloopers so clearly because Ricky's laugh is so loud.

Jenna [00:07:59] Uh huh.

Angela [00:07:59] He said at one point, Ricky even said, I'm not even a real actor. I just love how much fun they were having. I thought we should hear the bloopers.

Steve Carell [00:08:09] I’m working on an English character, his name is Reginald Poofta.

Ricky Gervais [00:08:16] Come on, come on!

Steve Carell [00:08:21] Sorry mate. I forgot me snotted cream.

Ricky Gervais [00:08:28] I’m so sorry. Alright. Ok. This is no good. I’m not even a real actor, let me out.

Jenna [00:08:40] All right. We have one more fan question for this cold open. It's from Mel W in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

Angela [00:08:46] Mel, what's you got?

Jenna [00:08:48] When Michael Scott meets David Brent waiting for an elevator, one thing that always seemed off, considering the fact that David Brent himself had once been in a documentary in the U.K., is why didn't he acknowledge or comment on the fact that there was a camera crew standing there filming Michael? It seems like a major opportunity for David to talk about his own documentary or to say something idiotic to the camera like he used to. Mel. This is so smart.

Angela [00:09:13] Yeah, I didn't even think of it when I was watching it.

Jenna [00:09:16] Me either.

Angela [00:09:16] But of course, David Brent would be very savvy to the camera crew. Unless we don't know when in time this happened.

Jenna [00:09:25] What do you mean?

Angela [00:09:26] What if this scene happened in the canon of the show before David Brent got a camera crew?! Maybe this inspired David Brent to be like, Will you come film me at my job in Slough?

Jenna [00:09:38] Oh, my gosh. My mind is bending right now because you're suggesting that maybe Dunder-Mifflin happened before Wernham Hogg happened.

Angela [00:09:48] Yeah. And that Dunder Mifflin and Michael Scott and his camera crew are what inspired David Brent to want to do the same thing?

Jenna [00:09:56] Yeah, I feel that. I feel him going back and being like, I met a guy in America.

Angela [00:10:01] They follow him around.

Jenna [00:10:02] With a camera.

Angela [00:10:02] Want to follow me around?

Jenna [00:10:02] I mean, come on.

Angela [00:10:04] Hey, BBC One, I have an idea for you.

Jenna [00:10:07] Wow. Good one, Ange.

Angela [00:10:09] You're welcome. You guys, there is no spoon. There is no spoon.

Jenna [00:10:15] We love you, Keanu.

Angela [00:10:16] We love you.

Jenna [00:10:17] All right. Fast fact number three. Are you ready? It's a deep dive. And it's a deep dive on Scrabble.

Angela [00:10:23] The game?

Jenna [00:10:23] The game. Because that's-.

Angela [00:10:25] That's what Gabe and Erin are playing. Okay.

Jenna [00:10:27] Yeah!

Angela [00:10:28] I love Scrabble. We just played it last weekend as our family game night.

Jenna [00:10:32] Well, every once in a while, I'll Google something that appears in an episode. And if it's interesting, I want to share. So I googled Time magazine, britannia.com, Wikipedia, and The New York Times, and here's what they told me. Scrabble was originally invented by an American architect named Alfred Mosher Butts in 1938, and he called it Criss Cross Words. Not Scrabble.

Angela [00:10:58] What else did Mr. Mosher Butts say?

Jenna [00:11:01] After he manufactured a few sets on his own, he was not able to sell it anywhere. No one wanted it. No one wanted Criss Cross Words.

Angela [00:11:09] Oh, Albert, you were so on to something. People didn't know.

Jenna [00:11:13] In 1948, a man named James Brunot, or Bruno, who was a resident of Newtown, Connecticut, he bought a Chris crosswords. He was like, I'm going to buy this game. And he loved it! In fact, he asked if he could buy the rights to manufacture the game in exchange for giving Butts a royalty on every unit sold. So he left most of the game unchanged, but he did do a couple of things. He rearranged the premium squares on the board.

Angela [00:11:43] Mm hmm.

Jenna [00:11:44] He simplified the rules a little bit. And he's the one who renamed the game Scrabble.

Angela [00:11:49] Sometimes it's all in a name.

Jenna [00:11:51] Did you know that Scrabble is a real word?

Angela [00:11:54] No.

Jenna [00:11:55] It means to scratch franatically.

Angela [00:11:58] Oh?

Jenna [00:11:58] Which is odd that you named this game about having to scratch a lot. Scrabble.

Angela [00:12:06] Scrabble.

Jenna [00:12:07] Yeah, I was up all last night scrabbling. Means you were scratching yourself.

Angela [00:12:12] So interesting.

Jenna [00:12:13] I need to scrabble. I have poison ivy. I need to scrabble.

Angela [00:12:17] I don't get it. I don't get it. I mean, I always thought scrabble meant when things were jumbled.

Jenna [00:12:21] Right?

Angela [00:12:22] Yeah.

Jenna [00:12:22] I don't know. All right. So Brunot and his family converted a former schoolhouse into their production facility, and they started making a whole bunch of these games. Guess what?

Angela [00:12:35] What?

Jenna [00:12:35] No one wanted them.

Angela [00:12:37] Oh, no. Did he go bankrupt?

Jenna [00:12:38] No. Because in 1952, Jack Straus, who was the president of Macy's, played the game on vacation. They had given some out to, like, hotels and stuff I guess.

Angela [00:12:50] Game changer.

Jenna [00:12:51] Yeah, he loved it. He couldn't believe that no one was selling this game. He said, I'm going to sell it at Macy's. Everyone has to have one. Guess what? Within a year, it had gone, I guess-.

Angela [00:13:03] Number one game.

Jenna [00:13:04] Viral. Yeah.

Angela [00:13:05] Yeah. Back in ye olde version of viral.

Jenna [00:13:07] Yes. Since then, it has been inducted into the National Toy Hall of Fame and the game is sold in 121 countries. It is available in more than 30 languages. The original inventor, Mr. Butts, said that he earned about $0.03 per game in royalties. Here's what he said: One third went to taxes. One third went to charity. And the last third enabled him to have an enjoyable life.

Angela [00:13:34] Hey...

Jenna [00:13:35] He also said that his wife was the best player of the game. She once scored 234 points for the word quixotic.

Angela [00:13:44] Wow.

Jenna [00:13:45] Q U I X O T I C.

Angela [00:13:48] Which means?

Jenna [00:13:49] Don't know.

Angela [00:13:52] I want to know what it means!

Jenna [00:13:53] I'll look it up.

Angela [00:13:54] Googling music, please? (SINGS) Be da do do do do do do do do...

Jenna [00:14:00] Okay. Ready? Quixotic means exceedingly idealistic, unrealistic and impractical.

Angela [00:14:12] Can you use it in a sentence, please?

Jenna [00:14:14] One might say creating a new board game is a quixotic project.

Angela [00:14:21] Way to bring it full circle, Fischer.

Jenna [00:14:22] Mmhmm. That's all I got, Ange.

Angela [00:14:26] Well, I have a Kinsey tidbit, and I have a digital clutter moment for you.

Jenna [00:14:32] Wow.

Angela [00:14:33] Kinsey tidbit is: The alt name for this episode was called The Closer.

Jenna [00:14:39] Hmm.

Angela [00:14:39] And not The Seminar.

Jenna [00:14:41] Okay.

Angela [00:14:41] So when you go back to shooting drafts, you'll see it being called The Closer. I don't know. I always find that interesting.

Jenna [00:14:48] I do as well.

Angela [00:14:50] And before we go to break, I just wanted to tell you guys that as I was reading the shooting draft for this episode, I noticed the shooting draft was dated October 21st, 2010. We shot this before we went on our holiday break.

Jenna [00:15:05] Yeah. What happened?

Angela [00:15:08] What happened? So I was like, what were we doing that week in October? I was curious. Here's what my digital clutter revealed. You and I were in the press that week! What?!

Jenna [00:15:20] Why, Angela?!

Angela [00:15:23] I was nominated for an award, and you were my plus one.

Jenna [00:15:28] What was the award and where did we go?

Angela [00:15:31] Here is what the press statement said. The sixth annual La Femme Film Festival Awards will be honoring Angela Bassett with the Pioneer Award, Virginia Madsen with the Visionary Award, Angela Kinsey with the New Establishment Award, Loretta Devine with the Thespian Award, and Maggie Wheeler with the Comedic Actress in Television Award at the festival's awards ceremony October 17th, 2010.

Jenna [00:15:58] Hmm.

Angela [00:15:59] I found a video from the red carpet.

Jenna [00:16:01] No!

Angela [00:16:02] Yes, but I'm really bummed because I couldn't find any pictures of us. And I know there are some out there. I looked everywhere. I found an email exchange between you and I, and we were debating about my dress and we decided on this sort of deep purple strapless number with an up do.

Jenna [00:16:19] Okay. I love how we would always consult one another on these choices, as if either of us are an expert in fashion or style.

Angela [00:16:28] I am telling you.

Jenna [00:16:29] Why did we not get other opinions? We are the worst people to ask.

Angela [00:16:34] I know. You and I are like right now in sweatpants and, like, baggy, like hoodies.

Jenna [00:16:40] Ridiculous.

Angela [00:16:41] We are no fashion plates. And, you know, it's a real struggle for us. But yet you helped me craft many a red carpet look.

Jenna [00:16:48] Same.

Angela [00:16:49] All right. Here it is.

Interviewer [00:16:51] And who are we talking to?

Angela [00:16:52] Hi, I'm Angela Kinsey from NBC's The Office.

Interviewer [00:16:55] And you've got to be excited to be here tonight. It didn't rain and it got quite a few people turning out. Tell me about the La Femme Film Fest. Is this your first time?

Angela [00:17:04] This is my first time. And I'm being honored with the New Establishment Award. I'm really excited about it. I love that this festival brings attention to women in the industry, whether they're film makers or they're in front of the camera or behind the camera. And on our show, we have a lot of women in pivotal positions. We have a camera operator. We have writers, producers, directors. Our first and second A.D. are women. So I was really passionate about being part of this.

Jenna [00:17:30] Angela!

Angela [00:17:31] I know. How about that?

Jenna [00:17:34] The tiny feminist in me is so proud of you for that sound bite. Way to raise up the ladies on our show.

Angela [00:17:40] Yeah, and my award is really beautiful. I still have it. It's like on my shelf. It's like this big crystal looking award. So that is what we were doing.

Jenna [00:17:49] Wow.

Angela [00:17:51] With that, let's go to break because when we get back, you guys, someone here at Office Ladies got their very own microphone.

Jenna [00:17:59] I can't wait.

Angela [00:18:01] We are back and Sam pointed out something. Sam, I can't believe we didn't think of this. Sam, you said it's been 100 and what?

Sam [00:18:08] It's 146 episodes. I was editing the last episode, and every time you talk to me and Cassi, it's me clearly on the mic, and then Cassi very faintly yelling. So, Cassi, you have a mic now.

Angela [00:18:19] Yay, Cassi! Say hi to everybody!

Cassi [00:18:21] Hello, everyone.

Angela [00:18:23] Yay!

Jenna [00:18:23] Listen to that!

Sam [00:18:24] So it took me146 episodes to occur to me that this studio is full of microphones.

Angela [00:18:29] And we could totally put one where you sit.

Jenna [00:18:31] Thank you.

Angela [00:18:31] Yay.

Cassi [00:18:32] Thank you, Sam.

Jenna [00:18:33] Well, how's this episode start, Angela?

Angela [00:18:35] It's going to start with Andy coming in and Erin very excitedly telling him that his first student has arrived.

Jenna [00:18:42] Yes. And he has a talking head where he explains that he attended a seminar last year called The Ten Secrets of Real Estate, which ended up being a scam to get him to buy a timeshare in Idaho. But what he realized is that he could throw his own scam seminar to get clients.

Angela [00:19:00] Yeah. I was curious what the ten secrets of real estate were. So I had to find out. According to the internet, this is what Andy would have heard. Number one, know your market. Number two, be responsive. Number three, listen to your clients. Number four, manage their expectations. Number five, list like a pro.

Jenna [00:19:24] Hmm.

Angela [00:19:25] Number six, build a contact list. Number seven.

Jenna [00:19:28] Number six is build a contact list?!

Angela [00:19:30] That's a little late.

Jenna [00:19:31] I mean, I don't want to tell the real estate people their business, but I feel like you might want to lead with that.

Angela [00:19:37] You might want to bump that up. Number seven, never stop marketing. Number eight, negotiate everything. Number nine, carve out a niche. Number ten, ask for reviews. These are some of the secrets to being a top notch real estate agent. I have to bring up my favorite Instagram account that list houses called Zillow Gone Wild on Instagram. Come on, guys. It's so good. Have you seen this, Jenna? Zillow Gone Wild?

Jenna [00:20:08] No.

Angela [00:20:09] Okay. It's an Instagram account of houses that are for sale.

Jenna [00:20:12] Okay.

Angela [00:20:13] And a lot of them look really normal from the outside. But then when you do the carousel of pictures, there's always something wacky. There's, like, a basement that looks like a dungeon. Or there was one the whole house looked like Tron, the movie.

Jenna [00:20:26] Oh, my gosh.

Angela [00:20:28] It's like, you know, the website Zillow. But if Zillow-.

Jenna [00:20:30] It's gone wild!

Angela [00:20:31] It's gone wild.

Jenna [00:20:32] Zillow Gone Wild.

Angela [00:20:33] You have to check it out. More students are going to arrive, including Mykokos.

Jenna [00:20:39] Yes, Mykonos. He is a Greek man. Oh, wait, it's Michael Scott pretending to be a Greek man.

Angela [00:20:47] But Erin's not sure.

Jenna [00:20:48] Michael gives a talking head where he explains he's the plant. Every great seminar has one. And I had a little observation here, Angela. I think that Mykonos bears a strong resemblance to Michael Scott season one, with the hair slicked back.

Angela [00:21:01] And the V-neck.

Jenna [00:21:02] Yeah. I was like, Oh my gosh, it's season one all over again.

Angela [00:21:07] I don't know about you, but I feel like I heard a little bit of Gru in Mykonos.

Jenna [00:21:11] A tiny bit of Gru.

Angela [00:21:13] Tiny bit of Gru from Minions.

Jenna [00:21:14] I'm with you.

Angela [00:21:15] Mm hmm.

Jenna [00:21:16] Andy has recruited a bunch of people to help with his seminar. One of them is Jim Halpert. But Jim notices someone come in to the office, and he has a big reaction, and he bails. He says, I'm not going to be your intro guy anymore, Andy.

Angela [00:21:31] Yeah. Tuna Turner bailing.

Jenna [00:21:34] Mm hmm.

Angela [00:21:35] Andy is devastated. How could Jim bail on him? By the way, the flier that Andy made, you know, he made official fliers. He put them out, I guess, around the city. I looked at it because I wanted to see who had what role in the seminar. Here's what it said: Dunder Mifflin and Sabre present a free seminar: How to Grow Your Small Business, Hosted by Andy Bernard. Introduction by Jim Halpert. Jim kicked the whole thing off.

Jenna [00:22:00] Yeah.

Angela [00:22:01] Small business expert Phyllis Smith and special guest speaker Dwight Schrute, the small business experts. And then there was a little asterisk and it said, Improve sales, increase customer retention, harness the power of the Internet, search engine revolution to take your small business global, use local radio to reach new customers.

Jenna [00:22:22] Wow.

Angela [00:22:23] That's everything on the flier.

Jenna [00:22:24] They're going to cover so much in this seminar.

Angela [00:22:26] They're going to take you global. This flier, of course, was made by Henry Saine.

Jenna [00:22:31] Andy has the talking head where he says this cannot go badly. He's a terrible salesman. He hasn't been making sales. He's counting on this.

Angela [00:22:39] Right. I went to the candy bag also for this talking head. No surprise, the character Andy has the most candy bag alts for this episode.

Jenna [00:22:49] Of course.

Angela [00:22:49] Of course. Here were two that were kind of funny. One, we reveal a whole new part of Andy's past. I love it when we learn a little something new.

Jenna [00:22:58] What now?

Angela [00:22:59] Andy says, Losing Jim is a big blow. If I don't find any new clients today, my future at Sabre is uncertain. And then what do I do? I majored in math with a minor in physics. Not exactly skills the paper sales industry is looking for.

Jenna [00:23:13] A minor in physics?

Angela [00:23:15] He majored in math.

Jenna [00:23:17] All I hear is that he could tell us all about the clacky balls. Math and physics. Right there.

Angela [00:23:23] Right there. His other candy bag alt. He throws a little shade at Pam.

Jenna [00:23:28] What?
